Articles.Content: I just launched my first satellite in my communication network. Did I do it right? I have a near equatorial orbit circularized near 450000m.

Without knowing what you need, sure that sounds fine. Though for full coverage you'll need at least 2 more, 120 degrees before and after that one in the same orbit.

Note: if you have ground stations turned on in the settings, you don't need a communications array at all.

It really depends on what your end goal is and the settings for the com network when you start the game.  If you intend to put up 3 around Kerbin to get constant coverage it is not required if you did not change "enable multiple ground stations", I play with single ground station and coms blackout so for me the first sat always goes into Keo orbit.  Ninja'd.

Well I was planning on having a few probes exploring the solar system. I changed the ground station settings though.

So you will have to be careful with your timing.  I usually put up a Keo in early career with lower powered antennae.  After that I put up polar scansat birds at the mun (I sometimes land a basic relay on the mun facing kerbin) and minmus.  This should give you pretty good Kerbin coverage.  Next I get a Sentinel between Eve/Kerbin with the highest power antennae available - This gives good coverage when the body you want to go to is blocked by Kerbol.  After that any first manned mission to any planet or moon deploys a relay sat.  I build all my vessels to have the ability to operate unmanned and I usually leave automated refuelling and rescue rigs at the low gravity moons around the system.  You still get blackouts from time to time - checking the map is important before planning burns but once you're used to it it's fairly easy to see when you will have signal or not.
